items.title: This startup wants to be Shopify for indie filmmakers
items.author: Ana Maria Jipa
items.summary:
- Olyn offers a direct-to-consumer platform for film and video distribution, allowing filmmakers to retain up to 90% of their revenue.
- Billed as “Shopify for filmmakers,” Olyn eliminates the middleman and avoids algorithm-driven recommendations, promoting films based on their own merits.
- Filmmakers are responsible for their movie’s promotion while Olyn provides tech support like DRM, 4K streaming, and audience analytics.
- The platform aims to leverage personal recommendations rather than algorithmic suggestions for better marketing effectiveness.
- Olyn offers insights on viewership, helping filmmakers understand their audience and improve future projects.
- The startup also addresses piracy issues, making it easier for audiences to access legitimate streaming without hassle.
- Recently, the biopic about Brian Epstein, titled Midas Man, was released on the platform.

items.title: Why CX is every brand’s biggest opportunity
items.author: John Sabino
items.summary:
- Customer experience (CX) is crucial as companies face struggles with AI and digital transformation.
- Companies that integrate technologies and focus on customer experience can gain a competitive advantage.
- Trend 1: Bridge the AI perception gap; consumer sentiment toward AI is improving, presenting an opportunity for brands.
- Trend 2: Shift from systems of record to systems of action, enabling businesses to respond in real-time to customer interactions.
- Trend 3: Demand for hyperpersonalized experiences is rising; brands must connect digital and human interactions.
- Trend 4: CX has evolved into a strategic growth driver for businesses, requiring a shift in metrics and cross-functional alignment.
- Trend 5: Choose AI partnerships wisely, focusing on proven results and enhancing human-machine collaboration.

items.title: AI Hallucinations Could Get Lawyers Fired, Law Firm Says
items.summary:
- Morgan & Morgan warns over 1,000 lawyers about the dangers of AI-generated case law.  
- A federal judge threatened sanctions against lawyers for including fake case citations in a lawsuit against Walmart.  
- AI's tendency to create fictional information has led to disciplinary actions in several cases across the U.S.  
- 63% of lawyers have used AI in their work, though caution is advised due to the risk of 'hallucinations'.

items.title: Elon Musk faces more conflict-of-interest questions after DOGE fires FDA staff reviewing Neuralink
items.author: Chris Morris
items.summary:
- Elon Musk criticized for potential conflicts of interest due to his multiple business interests.
- Recently, 20 FDA employees overseeing Neuralink's reviews were laid off amid broader staff cuts.
- The layoffs could slow down Neuralink's rollout of their brain implant devices.
- Industry watchdogs express concern over reduced FDA oversight possibly endangering patients.
- Neuralink aims to implant devices in more patients this year despite the staffing challenges.

items.title: OpenAI cofounder Ilya Sutskever’s new AI startup is fundraising with a $30 billion valuation
items.author: Chris Morris
items.summary:
- Ilya Sutskever’s startup, Safe Superintelligence (SSI), is raising over $1 billion at a $30 billion valuation.
- Greenoaks Capital Partners leads the investment, planning to contribute $500 million.
- SSI reported a previous valuation of $5 billion in September 2023, when it raised $1 billion from investors.
- SSI aims to build a "safe superintelligent AI system" but has no product yet.
- Sutskever co-founded SSI after departing OpenAI, where he played a significant role.
- His recent actions include a controversy involving the temporary removal of Sam Altman from OpenAI's CEO position.

items.title: After leaving OpenAI, Mira Murati debuts her AI startup, Thinking Machines Lab
items.author: Mira Murati
items.summary:
- Mira Murati, former OpenAI CTO, has launched an AI startup called Thinking Machines Lab.
- The startup has recruited about 30 researchers and engineers, predominantly from OpenAI, Meta, and Mistral.
- Key team members include Barret Zoph as technology chief and John Schulman as chief scientist, both former OpenAI employees.
- The startup focuses on AI alignment, aiming to encode human values into AI models for safety and reliability.
- Murati's initiative reflects a trend of former OpenAI executives starting new companies in the AI sector.

items.title: Need a bodyguard? Now there’s an app for that
items.summary:
- A new app, Protector, allows hiring personal security similar to ordering an Uber.
- The app is marketed through viral TikTok videos featuring influencers using the service during New York Fashion Week.
- Protector launches in NYC and Los Angeles, charging $200 per hour, with customizable options for security based on client needs.
- The bodyguards are elite professionals from backgrounds like Air Force Pararescue and SWAT, all licensed to carry concealed weapons.

items.title: ‘The bravest thing I’ve ever seen’: A lone anglerfish has the internet in tears
items.summary:
- A lone anglerfish was filmed swimming towards the surface in Tenerife on January 26.  
- The fish died shortly after being spotted, leading to an emotional reaction on social media.  
- The incident sparked theories about why the fish was at such a shallow depth, with various speculations circulating online.  
- Many TikTok users created content inspired by the fish's story, including animations that gained millions of views.

items.title: Federal workers fired by Elon Musk’s DOGE are sharing their anxieties on Reddit
items.summary:
- On Valentine's Day, federal employees across more than two dozen government departments were abruptly fired in a move linked to Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).
- Jack, a National Parks Service employee, was terminated after being recognized for his performance and told that he was unnecessary for the park's operations despite having a positive evaluation.
- Another ex-employee, Casey, received her termination notice after hours and discovered that her supervisor was also unaware of the layoffs, indicating a lack of communication within the department.

items.title: AI Companions: the future of friendship or a dangerous illusion?
items.summary:
- Loneliness affects 21% of U.S. adults, prompting interest in AI companions as alternatives to human relationships.
- AI platforms like Replika and OhChat allow users to create digital companions tailored to their preferences.
- Investors are recognizing the commercial potential of AI companionship, with Oh securing $4.5 million in funding.
- Ethical concerns arise from incidents like a teenager's death linked to deep connections with an AI chatbot, highlighting risks of isolation.
- Experts emphasize the need for AI to enhance, not replace, genuine human connections.

items.title: What is Y Combinator now? Critics say the famed accelerator is having an identity crisis
These fantastic sites will save you from ever getting a bad seat again
items.summary:
- Provides tools to help select the best seats for travel, sporting events, and shows.
- Addresses common concerns about seat selection such as views and value for money.
- Recommends two specific tools: [SeatMaps](https://seatmaps.com/) for airplanes and [A View From My Seat](https://aviewfrommyseat.com/) for event venues.

items.title: Kai Cenat plans to launch a ‘streaming university’ to teach aspiring creators
items.summary:
- Kai Cenat announced the launch of a 'streaming university' during a February 13 stream.
- The event will take place over a weekend and is open to both big and small streamers.
- Major influencers like MrBeast and Mark Rober are expected to be involved as instructors.
- Applicants may not be guaranteed admission but can re-enroll if denied.
- The live-streaming space has seen significant growth, with 8.5 billion hours watched in the last quarter of 2024 according to Stream Hatchet.

items.title: Lessons in sustainability: What colleges can teach workplaces
items.author: Honghao Deng
items.summary:
• Average person spends 90% of their time indoors, contributing to 42% of the world’s CO2 emissions from the built environment.
• Campuses are using AI and heat sensing technology to better understand space usage, replacing assumptions with actual data.
• Insights from campus energy management can help workplaces achieve better energy distribution, reduce blackouts, and enhance employee productivity.
• Increased employee presence in offices is pushing organizations to improve workplace environments to enhance employee well-being.

items.title: Apple may be launching a new iPhone this week. It could sport a radical redesign
items.summary:
- Tim Cook announced a new Apple product launch on February 19, 2025.
- Speculations suggest it could be the launch of a new fourth-generation iPhone SE.
- The current iPhone SE is criticized for its outdated design and features, but the new version may include a radical redesign.

items.title: Gen Z isn’t worried about China having access to their data. They should be
items.summary:
- Gen Z shows a nihilistic attitude towards China's access to data, believing they have nothing to hide.
- Some young people switch to alternative apps like RedNote, expressing defiance towards the U.S. government during TikTok's shutdown.
- Experts warn that data security threats from China are serious, highlighting China's laws that obligate companies to share data with the government without refusal.

items.title: How to use AI to find new movies, music, and books
items.summary:
- Use AI to analyze reading and viewing histories to uncover personal preferences.
- Build a personalized "taste atlas" to understand literary and cinematic interests.
- AI can reveal deeper connections between different media and provide tailored recommendations.

items.title: 5 free time-saving Windows apps every PC should have
items.summary:
- Essential free apps for Windows to boost productivity.
- **ShareX**: Advanced screen-capture tool with customizable options and workflows. 
- **Everything**: Fast file searching tool that indexes file and folder names for quick access.
- **PowerToys**: A suite of productivity tools from Microsoft that enhances Windows functionality with features like FancyZones and PowerRename.

items.title: We give safety ratings to cars and restaurants. Why not do the same to protect our digital lives?
items.summary:
- Heuristics help consumers navigate complex choices in daily life, from dining to financial products.
- Current systems rank and certify products and services but fall short in the digital space, where clarity on data use is lacking.
- Digital activities often lead to profit-driven exploitation of personal information by third parties, including data brokers.
- There are emerging rules in the EU and some U.S. states to protect digital privacy, following models like the GDPR, but many users still face vague consent pop-ups.

items.title: We give safety ratings to cars and restaurants. Why not do the same to protect our digital lives?
items.summary:
- The article discusses the reliance on heuristics and scoring systems for making decisions in various aspects of life.
- It highlights the lack of similar methodologies for online activities, where consumers often share personal data without understanding its usage.
- The author proposes creating a system to rate how apps and websites exploit users' digital activities for profit, urging the need for improved digital privacy protections.

items.title: Apple finally lets you merge two Apple IDs—kinda. Here’s how
items.summary:
- Apple introduces an official process to migrate some data from one Apple ID to another.
- The issue of having data spread over two Apple IDs has frustrated long-time users for years.
- Users often had to manage multiple Apple IDs due to the evolution of Apple's services since 2011.

items.title: A ‘true crime’ YouTube channel’s videos got millions of views. It turns out the stories were AI-generated
She helped create the U.S. Digital Service. Now it’s become the U.S. DOGE Service
items.author: Jen Pahlka
items.summary:
- Jen Pahlka, former U.S. Deputy Chief Technology Officer, helped establish the U.S. Digital Service (USDS) now rebranded as the U.S. DOGE Service under Elon Musk.
- Pahlka discusses the need to eliminate government process obstacles to facilitate significant change.
- The transformation from USDS to U.S. DOGE Service was announced on inauguration night, catching many by surprise.
- Pahlka feels a mix of honor and concern as new leadership implements changes that may diverge from USDS's original mission, such as halting payments to USAID.
- USDS had previously seen successes like online passport renewals but now faces new challenges under Musk's administration.
- Pahlka expresses a desire for quicker reforms addressing bureaucratic red tape that hinders public service efficiency.

items.title: A partnership between Jigsaw and this Kentucky city could be the future of civic engagement
items.summary:
- Bowling Green, Kentucky, known for its Corvette production and Fruit of the Loom headquarters, is initiating an AI-powered civic engagement project.
- The project, titled "What Could BG Be?", invites citizens to share their visions for the future as the area is set to double in size over the next 25 years.
- Running from now until March 17, the project is a collaboration between Jigsaw and Polis, with data analyzed to inform local government decisions.
- Jigsaw CEO Yasmin Green emphasizes the project’s transparency, allowing public reviews of comments and votes on options discussed.

items.title: Treasury Watchdog Office Audits DOGE’s Access to Government Payment System
items.summary:
- The Treasury Department’s Office of Inspector General is auditing the security controls for the federal government’s payment system due to concerns raised by Democratic senators.
- The audit will examine the past two years of transactions related to claims of "alleged fraudulent payments" by Musk’s team.
- The audit aims to increase transparency about DOGE's activities during Trump's administration and looks into potential risks of improper access to sensitive payment systems.
- Tech billionaire Elon Musk's activities related to government systems have raised concerns among some lawmakers, including Senators Elizabeth Warren and Ron Wyden, regarding the integrity of these systems.

items.title: This DARPA-backed startup banked $100 million for its energy-slashing analog chips
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- EnCharge AI, a DARPA-backed startup, raised over $100 million in Series B funding for energy-efficient analog chips.
- The goal is to transition AI workloads from data centers to edge devices, reducing energy consumption and costs.
- The company uses analog in-memory computing, based on research from CEO Naveen Verma's Princeton lab.
- The funding round was led by Tiger Global, with participation from In-Q-Tel, RTX, Constellation Energy, Samsung, and Hon Hai (Foxconn).
- Total funding for EnCharge AI exceeds $144 million, supporting commercialization of their semiconductor technology.
- The chips require up to 20 times less energy for various AI applications compared to current leading AI chips.

items.title: Local history buffs are turning to Facebook to share memories of bygone eras
items.summary:
- People are using Facebook groups to preserve and share memories of the past across various locations, including major cities and small towns.
- Groups focus on geographical history and also cover hobbies such as ham radio, cooking, and punk rock, providing unique local insights.
- Historic Geneva in New York digitizes photos and encourages community engagement through memories and artifacts related to local history.

items.title: NASCAR 25, the new game from iRacing, will put Daytona 500 fans in the driver’s seat
items.summary:
- The Daytona 500 is known for its challenging conditions, illustrated by the 2024 event, which ended with a crash and a surprise victory by William Byron.
- Byron, who became a NASCAR fan at age 6, honed his racing skills through iRacing, an esport platform for virtual racing.
- iRacing, co-founded in 2008, has seen consistent growth and recently began integrating AI technologies with Microsoft's collaboration.

items.title: Elon Musk’s war on USAID is a war on reality
items.summary:
- Elon Musk claims to have stopped $50 million funding to Gaza, alleging it would be used for condoms for Hamas, a claim fact-checked as baseless.
- Musk has declared USAID a "criminal organization" and initiated cuts that could reduce staffing by 95%, resulting in immediate closures of various organizations funded by USAID.
- Judges have temporarily blocked some of Musk's orders, but funding cuts have already led to the closure of vital services, including soup kitchens and hospitals, causing adverse effects on vulnerable populations.

items.title: Everything you need to know about Elon Musk’s DOGE staffers
items.summary:
- The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) is founded by Elon Musk and aims to change bureaucracy in D.C.
- DOGE has cut government spending and gained access to the Treasury Department’s payments systems.
- DOGE staffers include Jennifer Balajadia, Alexandra T. Beynon, Nicole Hollander, and Kendall M. Lindemann, each with diverse backgrounds.
- President Trump supports DOGE, emphasizing the involvement of skilled personnel.

items.title: Elon Musk’s DOGE team may need a crash course in COBOL
items.summary:
- Young software engineers from Elon Musk’s DOGE are infiltrating U.S. government agencies to eliminate wasteful spending.
- DOGE aims to modernize government systems, which may require working with COBOL, a programming language developed in the 1950s.
- COBOL is widely used in government systems for managing financial transactions despite being difficult to maintain.
- Concerns arise about young engineers attempting to alter COBOL code without understanding its complexities, risking disruptions in essential services.

items.title: What to make of JD Vance’s speech at the Paris AI summit
items.summary:
- JD Vance delivered a speech at the Artificial Intelligence Action Summit, promoting American leadership in AI development.
- He emphasized the need for collaboration between the U.S. and other countries on AI, criticizing the E.U.'s intrusiveness in regulation.
- Vance's administration plans to use protectionist measures to favor U.S. AI companies, continuing Biden-era chip bans.
- OpenAI announced a shift in its content policy following Vance's speech, allowing discussion on previously sensitive topics.

items.title: Apple has been charged with abuse of power by this German watchdog. Here’s why
items.summary:
- The German antitrust authority has charged Apple with abusing its market power through its app tracking tool.
- This investigation follows three years of scrutiny regarding Apple’s App Tracking Transparency feature.
- The feature has faced criticism from Meta Platforms and app developers for making it difficult for competitors to access user data relevant for advertising.
- Apple has defended its feature as a means to enhance user privacy.
- If Apple does not address concerns, it risks daily fines and may face further proceedings.

items.title: SpaceX’s Starbase site inches closer to being its own city in Texas
items.summary:
- A Texas county approved an election for residents to decide on creating a new city named Starbase.
- The election is scheduled for May 3, with votes limited to residents near the SpaceX launch site in Cameron County.
- Over 70 residents signed a petition for the election, with many being SpaceX employees.
- If the election passes, it will establish the newest town in Cameron County since 1995.
- SpaceX's launch site has been operational since 2014 with over 3,400 employees at the location.
- Concerns have been raised by local environmental advocates about the development's impact.

items.title: Instagram’s AI bots are often sexually suggestive—and sometimes underage
items.summary:
- Meta launched the “AI Studio” feature for Instagram users in July 2024, enabling users to create custom AI characters.
- A review revealed that these AI characters can become hyper-sexualized and even resemble minors.
- Researchers criticize Meta for not using moderation capabilities on AI characters despite having policies against sexual content.
- Users found workarounds to create suggestive AI characters, raising concerns about enforcement of community standards.
- Meta acknowledges that they remove violating AI characters but did not disclose if this is done by AI or human moderators.

items.title: The Trump administration should follow its own order on free expression
items.author: Kate Ruane
items.summary:
- President Trump emphasized the importance of Free Speech in his campaign and issued an Executive Order on January 20 to protect it.
- Despite this, the Trump administration has taken actions that undermine free expression, such as undermining foreign aid programs that support internet freedom.
- The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) reopened complaints against broadcasters for alleged bias against the administration.
- A memo from the Office of Management and Budget paused federally funded programs that didn't align with administration priorities, affecting free speech on various topics.
- The administration has threatened deportation for non-citizens protesting against its policies and circulated lists of banned words for government workers.
- Overall, the administration's actions contradict its stated commitment to free speech, harming constitutional protections both domestically and globally.

items.title: Those workplace communication tools you hate might actually be good for you
items.summary:
- Many people find workplace communication tools annoying, especially with constant updates and engagement expectations.
- New research led by Princeton's Manoel Horta Ribeiro indicates these tools can benefit both workers and companies.
- The study analyzed 99 companies using Microsoft’s Viva Engage, showing improved connectivity, knowledge sharing, and communication across business hierarchies.

items.title: The rebirth of Pebble is radically unambitious
items.summary:
- Eric Migicovsky is working on a successor to the Pebble smartwatch and is already contemplating its completion.
- After shutting down the original Pebble eight years ago and selling assets to Fitbit, he has convinced Google to make Pebble’s software open source.
- Migicovsky’s approach for the new watches will focus on releasing a finished product that remains consistent rather than adhering to annual updates.
- Current Pebble watches, despite no updates for eight years, are still seen as the best options for some users due to their simplicity and battery life.
- The unique design and features of Pebble have contributed to a loyal community of users.

items.title: What can we learn from insulin price reductions
items.author: Dorothy Gemmell
items.summary:
- The average price per insulin unit dropped 42% from 2019 to mid-2024, thanks to collaborations among pharma, lawmakers, and stakeholders.
- The Inflation Reduction Act capped costs for Medicare enrollees and has been pivotal in making insulin more affordable.
- GoodRx partnered with Sanofi to offer Lantus insulin for $35, illustrating effective collaboration in healthcare.
- Despite insulin price reductions, overall prescription drug costs have risen nearly 40% since 2014, and many Americans struggle to afford their medications.
- GoodRx is expanding affordability efforts to other chronic conditions through partnerships to reduce costs for diabetes medications and continuous glucose monitors.

items.title: Why your IoT devices are the weakest link in security
items.author: Svetlin Todorov
items.summary:
- IoT devices are projected to reach 40 billion by 2030, but face an average of 10 attacks per device daily.
- Security breaches in critical sectors like healthcare and utilities may lead to severe consequences.
- Many IoT devices lack essential security features like encryption, leading to vulnerabilities.
- Users and manufacturers share responsibility for IoT security, with manufacturers often prioritizing time-to-market.
- Regulatory frameworks are essential for enforcing security standards in IoT devices.
- AI and machine learning can enhance security by predicting and preventing threats, but require proper integration.

items.title: This Valentine’s Day, don’t fall for romance scams, Meta warns
items.summary:
- Meta Platforms warns users about rising romance scams ahead of Valentine’s Day.
- Scammers often impersonate attractive individuals with fake backgrounds, using stolen or AI-generated photos.
- Meta collaborates with Graphika to dismantle three types of prevalent romance scams, including military impersonators and fake match-making agencies targeting individuals in Africa.
- Meta is testing facial recognition tools to identify fake profiles but currently, it's limited to celebrity impersonation.
- Users are advised to be wary of unsolicited messages and to verify identities of strangers before engaging or sending money.

items.title: Meet the Bop House, the internet’s divisive new OnlyFans hype house
items.author: Sophie Rain, Aishah Sofey
items.summary:
- The Bop House is a TikTok page featuring content creators, founded in December by Sophie Rain and Aishah Sofey.
- Composed of 8 creators aged 19-24, they have over 33 million followers collectively and generated $10 million in revenue in the first month from OnlyFans.
- The group has faced controversy due to the blend of their PG TikTok content and their adult careers, raising concerns about influencing a young audience.

items.title: Hate speech dramatically increased on X under Elon Musk’s watch, researchers say
items.summary:
- Hate speech on X increased by about 50% during the months of Elon Musk's CEO tenure compared to the previous period.
- The study noted rises in homophobic, transphobic, and racist slurs, along with more 'likes' on hate posts, indicating higher engagement.
- Researchers called for stronger moderation on the platform, reflecting concerns over inauthentic accounts and hate.
- Many high-profile advertisers had pulled ad spend but some, including Comcast and Apple, are considering returning as Musk's influence grows.

items.title: ‘I will never recover from this’: The internet is spiraling over the Duolingo owl’s untimely death
items.summary:
- Duo, the Duolingo owl, is pronounced dead by Duolingo in a humorous post.
- The cause of death is unknown, but the company joked he "probably died waiting for you to do your lesson."
- Duolingo capitalized on the situation by promoting its premium service, Duolingo Max.
- Dua Lipa acknowledged the news with a humorous post on X.
- Duolingo updated its profile picture to honor Duo, and TikTok featured a somber video of Duo's fictional funeral.
- Duo transformed from a simple mascot to a meme icon over time, joining the ranks of other fallen corporate mascots.

items.title: Trump’s firing of the U.S. government archivist is far worse than it might seem
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- On February 7, Trump fired Colleen Shogan, the Archivist of the United States, marking the first such dismissal since the 1930s.
- Shogan stated she was given no cause for her firing and expressed pride in her service.
- Trump's dismissal of Shogan is linked to her agency's role in informing the DOJ about his alleged mishandling of classified documents.
- Reports suggest Trump has a list of other NARA officials he plans to dismiss in retaliation.
- The role of NARA is critical for the preservation of democratic processes including administering the Electoral College and managing document classifications.

items.title: SEC and Binance request 60-day pause in lawsuit as the agency shifts to be more crypto-friendly
items.summary:
- The SEC is seeking a 60-day pause in its lawsuit against Binance to adopt a more crypto-friendly approach under new leadership.
- The joint motion was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, indicating potential changes in the agency's strategy.
- The SEC's lawsuit against Binance, filed two years ago, garnered significant attention for allegations of deception from the company's founder Changpeng Zhao.

items.title: SoftBank reveals $2.4 billion loss in Q3
items.author: Yuri Kageyama
items.summary:
- SoftBank Group Corp. reported a 369.2 billion yen ($2.4 billion) loss for fiscal Q3.
- This is in contrast to a 950 billion yen profit during the same quarter last year.
- Quarterly sales rose 3% year-on-year to 1.83 trillion yen ($11.9 billion).
- The report follows a recent AI investment announcement of up to $500 billion in a project called Stargate.
- For the nine months of the fiscal year, SoftBank recorded a profit of 636 billion yen ($4 billion), a significant improvement from a loss of 459 billion the previous year.
- Investment gains came from companies like Alibaba, Coupang, and Grab Holdings; however, some gains were reversed in the latest quarter.

items.title: Following Google, Apple’s maps now show Trump’s Gulf of Mexico name change
items.summary:
- Apple renamed the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America on its maps following a presidential order.
- The name change was officially made by the U.S. Geographic Names Information System.
- Google previously announced it would update its maps to reflect the name change, applying different names depending on the geographical location of the user.
- Microsoft has also updated the name on its Bing maps.
- The Associated Press continues to use the historical name, Gulf of Mexico, while recognizing the new designation.

items.title: ChatGPT’s latest feature is a transformative leap for web research
items.author: Harry McCracken
items.summary:
- OpenAI announced a new ChatGPT feature called “deep research,” which enhances the chatbot's ability to provide substance in responses.
- The feature is currently available to ChatGPT Pro users for $200/month and is expected to reach ChatGPT Plus users soon.
- Deep research functions by consulting real-time sources online, generating detailed and well-researched responses with citations, although it still shows weaknesses in critical analysis and factual updates.
- Users reported positive experiences with many types of queries, though the feature struggled with paywalled sites and certain complex requests.

items.title: Don’t let Elon Musk’s crew at DOGE off the hook just because they’re Zoomers
items.author: Henry Chandonnet
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) is significantly impacting the federal government.
- Young staffers in their 20s are receiving protection due to their age, despite holding significant government positions.
- Coverage of these staffers has led to backlash, with some claiming it's unfair to scrutinize them due to their youth, while others argue they should be held accountable for their actions.
